subsection.title: Radical Equations

assemblage.p: A radical equation is one in which the variable appears under a radical.

statement.p: If you drop a penny from the top of the Sears Tower in Chicago, it will take 9.5 seconds to reach the ground. Find the height of the Sears Tower in meters by solving the equation 9.5=\sqrt{\dfrac{h}{4.9}}

solution.p: To solve the equation, we undo the operations performed on h. To undo the operation of taking a square root, we can square both sides of the equation. Remember that we undo the operations in the opposite order, as follows.

ol.li: Isolate the radical on one side of the equation.
Square both sides of the equation.
Continue as usual to solve for the variable.

answer.p: One in which the variable appears under a radical.

solution.p: We square both sides of the equation to produce an equation without radicals. (\sqrt{x-3})^2 \amp = 4^2 x-3 \amp = 16 x \amp = 19 You can check that x=19 satisfies the original equation.

subsection.title: Extraneous Solutions
subsection.p: The technique of squaring both sides may introduce extraneous solutions. (Recall that an extraneous solution is a value that is not a solution to the original equation.) For example, consider the equation \sqrt{x+2}=-3 Squaring both sides gives us (\sqrt{x+2})^2 \amp =(-3)^2 x+2 \amp = 9 x \amp = 7 However, if we substitute into the original equation, we see that it is not a solution. \sqrt{\blert{7}+2} = \sqrt{9} = 3 \not= -3 The value x=7 is a solution to the squared equation, but not to the original equation. In this case, the original equation has no solution.

statement.p: When we solve a radical equation, what causes extraneous solutions to be introduced?

answer.p: Squaring both sides of the equation.

assemblage.p: Whenever we square both sides of an equation, we must check the solutions in the original equation.

subsection.p: If a radical equation involves several terms, it is easiest to isolate the radical term on one side of the equation before squaring both sides.

solution.p: We first isolate the radical by subtracting from both sides to get \sqrt{8-2x} = x-4 Now we square both sides to obtain (\sqrt{8-2x})^2 \amp = (x-4)^2 8-2x \amp =x^2-8x+16 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Write the quadratic equation in standard form.}} 0 \amp = x^2-6x+8 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Factor the right side.}} 0 \amp = (x-4)(x-2) The possible solutions are x=4 and x=2. We check both of these in the original equation.

\blert{\text{Check:}} For x=\blert{4}, 4+\sqrt{8-2(\blert{4})} \amp = \blert{4}? 4+\sqrt{0} \amp = 4? 4 \amp = 4 For x=\blert{2}, 4+\sqrt{8-2(\blert{2})} \amp = \blert{2}? 4+\sqrt{4} \amp =2? 6 \amp \not= 2 Thus, x=2 is an extraneous solution. The only solution to the original equation is x=4.

warning.p: When squaring both sides of an equation, we must be careful to square the entire expression on either side of the equal sign. It is incorrect to square each term separately. Thus, in , it would not be correct to write ( \sqrt{8-2x})^2 = x^2-4^2 ~~~~~~~~~~~~\alert{\text{Incorrect!}}

statement.p: True or false: to solve a radical equation, we should square each term of the equation. Explain.

answer.p: False. We should square each side of the equation.

subsection.title: Equations with Cube Roots
subsection.p: We can also solve equations in which the variable appears under a cube root.

solution.p: We first isolate the cube root. 15-2\sqrt[3]{x-4} \amp = 9 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Subtract 15 from both sides.}} -2\sqrt[3]{x-4} \amp = -6 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by}~-2.} \sqrt[3]{x-4} \amp = 3 Next, we undo the cube root by cubing both sides of the equation. (\sqrt[3]{x-4})^3 \amp = 3^3 x-4 \amp = 27 Finally, we add 4 to both sides to find the solution, x=31. We do not have to check for extraneous solutions when we cube both sides of an equation, but it is a good idea to check the solution for accuracy anyway.

statement.p: How can we solve an equation if the variable appears under a cube root?

answer.p: Isolate the cube root, then cube both sides.

subsection.title: Extraction of Roots
subsection.p: Now we'll compare solving radical equations, where we square both sides, with quadratic equations, where we may be able to take square roots of both sides.

statement.p: Is it true that 1+3\sqrt{2} = 4\sqrt{2}? Why or why not?

answer.p: No. 1 and 3\sqrt{2} are not like terms.
